keyTakeAways: A man named Billy Joe Cagle was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family alerted police that he was armed and intended to 'shoot it up' at the airport.
Cagle was not armed at the time of arrest but police found an AR-15 assault rifle in his vehicle parked outside the airport.

Cagle faces multiple charges including terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assaults, possession of a firearm in commission of a felony, and being a convicted felon in possession of a firearm.

He is also charged with federal offenses such as attempted violence at an international airport, interstate communications containing threats to injure, and being a convicted felon in possession of a firearm.
Cagle has a prior conviction for marijuana possession over two decades ago, according to Georgia Department of Corrections records.
The FBI is assisting in the investigation.
Atlanta Mayor Andre Dickens described the situation as a 'tragedy averted' due to early intervention by Cagle’s family and law enforcement coordination.
Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport is the busiest airport in the world, handling over 108 million passengers in 2024 and marking its centennial milestone this year.
Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem expressed gratitude that the individual was taken into custody before any harm occurred.
The incident underscores the importance of community vigilance and interagency coordination in preventing mass violence at high-traffic public facilities.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man named Billy Joe Cagle, who lives in Cartersville, Georgia, was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family alerted authorities that he was armed and planning to 'shoot it up' at the facility. Though not armed at the time of arrest, police discovered an AR-15 assault rifle in his vehicle. Cagle faces multiple state and federal charges, including terroristic threats, attempted aggravated assaults, and possession of a firearm by a convicted felon. Authorities credit the incident’s averted outcome to early warnings from his family and coordinated action between Cartersville and Atlanta police. The FBI is assisting in the investigation. The airport, the world’s busiest, is a critical transportation hub, and the incident underscores the importance of public vigilance and inter-agency cooperation in preventing mass violence at high-traffic locations. Federal officials, including Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem and Atlanta Mayor Andre Dickens, have publicly acknowledged the incident as a 'tragedy averted.'
title: Man arrested inside Atlanta airport after making threats to ‘shoot it up’
